content.summary: English version of the Ramayana epic

rama_birth.content: Rama was born in Ayodhya as the eldest son of King Dasharatha. He was born along with his three brothers - Bharata, Lakshmana, and Shatrughna - after King Dasharatha performed the Putrakameshti sacrifice conducted by sage Rishyasringa.

sita_location.content: Ravana kept Sita captive in the Ashoka garden (Ashoka Vatika) in Lanka. This beautiful grove was guarded by female demons (Rakshasis) who were ordered to torment Sita and make her submit to Ravana's wishes.

exile_reason.content: Rama went into exile for 14 years due to Queen Kaikeyi's two boons. She demanded that her son Bharata be crowned king and Rama be sent to the forest for fourteen years. King Dasharatha was bound by his promise and had to fulfill these demands.

dasharatha_sons.content: King Dasharatha had four sons: Rama (eldest, son of Kausalya), Bharata (son of Kaikeyi), Lakshmana and Shatrughna (twin sons of Sumitra). All were born after the Putrakameshti sacrifice.

hanuman_lanka.content: Hanuman burned Lanka with his tail after being captured by Ravana's forces. When they set his tail on fire, he used it to burn down the golden city, sparing only the Ashoka Grove where Sita was kept.

ravana_death.content: Ravana was killed by Rama in the final battle of Lanka. Despite his ten heads, Rama defeated him by aiming at his navel where his life force was stored, using the divine Brahmastra weapon.

bharata_meeting.content: Bharata met Rama at Chitrakuta and begged him to return. When Rama refused, Bharata took his sandals and ruled as regent, placing the sandals on the throne until Rama's return.

bridge_construction.content: The monkey army built a bridge across the ocean to Lanka. The stones floated because the monkeys wrote 'Rama' on them, demonstrating the power of the divine name.

sita_swayamvara.content: Sita's swayamvara was held by King Janaka where the condition was to string and break Lord Shiva's mighty bow. Many kings tried but failed. Rama not only strung the bow but broke it, winning Sita's hand in marriage.

hanuman_lanka.content: Hanuman burned Lanka with his tail. When captured by Ravana's forces, they set his tail on fire as punishment. Hanuman used this opportunity to leap across Lanka, setting the golden city ablaze while keeping the Ashoka grove safe where Sita was held.

ravana_death.content: Ravana was killed by Rama in the final battle of Lanka. Despite having ten heads that would regenerate when cut, Rama finally killed him by shooting a Brahmastra arrow into his navel where his life force was stored, as revealed by Vibhishana.

bharata_meeting.content: Bharata met Rama at Chitrakuta and pleaded with him to return and rule the kingdom. When Rama refused, citing his duty to fulfill his father's promise, Bharata took Rama's sandals (paduka) and placed them on the throne, ruling as Rama's regent.

ahalya_liberation.content: Ahalya was liberated from her curse by Rama's touch. She had been turned to stone due to Indra's deception and her husband Gautama's curse. When Rama's feet touched the stone, she was restored to her original form and freed from the curse.

jatayu_death.content: Jatayu, the noble vulture and friend of King Dasharatha, fought valiantly with Ravana to rescue Sita. Ravana cut off his wings, and the dying Jatayu informed Rama and Lakshmana about Sita's abduction and the direction Ravana had taken her.

sugriva_alliance.content: Rama formed an alliance with Sugriva, the exiled monkey prince. In return for killing his brother Vali and restoring his kingdom of Kishkindha, Sugriva promised to help find Sita by sending his vast army of monkeys to search for her.

vibhishana_surrender.content: Vibhishana, Ravana's righteous younger brother, abandoned Lanka and surrendered to Rama. Despite being Ravana's brother, he chose dharma over family loyalty and provided crucial intelligence that helped Rama defeat Ravana.

bridge_construction.content: The monkeys built a magnificent bridge across the ocean to Lanka. Led by the architect monkeys Nala and Nila, the entire monkey army worked together, with stones floating on water by the power of Rama's name written on them.

kumbhakarna_death.content: Kumbhakarna, Ravana's giant brother who slept for six months at a time, was awakened for the war. Despite knowing Ravana was wrong, he fought for family honor and was killed by Rama after a fierce battle.

rama_coronation.content: After completing 14 years of exile and defeating Ravana, Rama returned to Ayodhya in the Pushpaka Vimana. He was crowned king by sage Vasishtha, establishing the golden age known as Rama Rajya, characterized by justice, prosperity, and righteousness.

shabari_devotion.content: Shabari, an elderly tribal woman and devotee of Rama, offered him berries that she had tasted to ensure they were sweet. Rama accepted them with love, showing that true devotion transcends social barriers and that God values the purity of heart over social status.

maricha_deception.content: Maricha, Ravana's uncle, transformed into a beautiful golden deer to lure Rama away from Sita. When Rama killed him, Maricha cried out in Rama's voice for help, deceiving Sita and Lakshmana and enabling Ravana to abduct Sita.

lakshmana_rekha.content: Lakshmana drew a protective line (Lakshmana Rekha) around their hut before leaving to help Rama. He warned Sita not to cross this magical boundary for her safety. However, Ravana, disguised as a sage, tricked her into crossing the line.

ocean_crossing.content: Hanuman made a mighty leap across the ocean to reach Lanka in search of Sita. He enlarged himself to the size of a mountain and flew over the 100-yojana wide ocean, overcoming various obstacles including sea monsters and demonesses.

indrajit_battle.content: Indrajit (Meghnad), Ravana's son, was a powerful warrior who could fight while invisible. He severely wounded Rama and Lakshmana with his serpent arrows. He was eventually killed by Lakshmana after a fierce battle.

sanjivani_herb.content: When Lakshmana was mortally wounded by Indrajit's arrows, Hanuman flew to the Himalayas to bring the life-saving Sanjivani herb. Unable to identify the specific herb, he carried the entire mountain, saving Lakshmana's life.

Rama.description: The protagonist, prince of Ayodhya, incarnation of Vishnu

Sita.description: Rama's wife, daughter of King Janaka, incarnation of Lakshmi

Hanuman.description: Monkey devotee of Rama, son of wind god
